british farm minister attacks subsidies farm subsidies and protectionist moves threaten healthy trade on both sides of the atlantic michael jopling british minister of agriculture fisheries and food warned it would not be sensible to provoke another dispute between europe and the united states jopling said in remarks prepared for an evening speech but some things are clear and they apply on both sides of the atlantic we cannot continue to pile up stocks while world demand shrinks he said governments must not operate farm policies as if they were purely domestic affairs with no impact on others they also have to recognize that they cannot in the long run develop healthy and stable farm sector on the basis of protectionism and excessive subisdies and above all europe and the united states have too many common interests to make it worthwhile to engage in trade wars and competitive export subsidies which end by benefitting no one he added it is crucial that the united states and the european community remain friends jopling who is member of the ec agriculture committee was in indiana to visit several farms prior to talks with officials in washington later this week jopling also criticized recent proposal still under consideration by the ec for tax on vegetable and fish oils he said his government would oppose such move because we do not think it is correct that shortage of funds to support ec farmers should be alleviated by raising money at the consumer expense

japan in last ditch effort to save chip pact japan has launched last ditch effort to salvage its computer micro chip pact with the united states sending letter to top american policy makers setting out its case and instructing its producers to cut output further we must make our utmost effort to ward off any catastrophe ministry of international trade and industry miti deputy director general masaji yamamoto told reporters if hasty action is taken in the united states it will create very serious problems the reagan administration economic policy is expected to meet thursday to review japanese compliance with the bilateral agreement hammered out last year under the pact tokyo agreed to stop selling cut price chips in world markets and to increase its imports of american semiconductors washington has accused japan of reneging on the deal by selling low priced chips in asia and by failing to boost american imports and has threatened to take retaliatory action in an effort to save the agreement miti is asking japanese chip makers to limit production in the hope that will boost domestic demand and reduce the incentive to export yamamoto said that japan will slash output of 256 kilobit dynamic random access and erasable programmable read only memory chips by 11 pct in the second quarter this follows cutback of more than 20 pct in the first three months of the year he said the cutbacks were already drying up the supply of chips available for export through unregulated distributors in the so called grey market we have almost no grey market he said supply is diminishing to help ensure that the cutbacks are implemented miti called in the president of japan largest semiconductor maker nec corp lt nipn last week he said it is also issuing specific instructions on production to the japanese subsidiary of lt texas instruments inc trade and industry minister hajime tamura spelled out the steps japan was taking to salvage the pact and appealed for understanding in letter to top american policy makers the letter was sent today to secretary of state george schultz treasury secretary james baker commerce secretary malcolm baldrige and trade representative clayton yeutter the four who make up the economic policy council are expected to consider evidence presented by chip maker micron technology inc lt dram of cut price japanese sales in hong kong yamamoto admitted that lt oki electric industry co hong kong subsidiary had sold chips at an inappropriate level but denied that it was dumping chips at rock bottom prices if the united states uses this as proof of dumping we will present our rebuttal he said the sales though were inappropriate in the light of miti advice to semiconductor makers to sell chips at well above production costs to avoid any hint of dumping he said he also called the case strange but he stopped short of endorsing japanese newspaper accusations that oki had been trapped into making the sales he did say though that micron publicized the invoice documenting the sales on the same day they were made and that oki was unable to locate the person who had bought the chips when it tried to buy them back last week

exports body gets new executive director export credits guarantee department has named malcolm stephens director of export finance at barclay bank plc and former career civil servant at ecgd for 17 years to the post of executive director department spokesman said stephens replaces jack gill who is retiring early aged 57 drop in the ecgd business volume and rise in its debt to the exchequer have led to criticism in parliament in recent years stephens said the fall in business volume was top convern adding that the department may have to compete more aggressively with private insurance firms providing similar services the department annual report for the year ended march 31 1986 showed exports insured by the department fell to 15 billion stg from 17 billion the year before while its debt to the exchequer almost doubled to 756 mln stg stephens said he had no specific list of changes but among his chief concerns was the weakened condition of lesser developed countries and their ability to pay for their imports the agency will have to review its policies on insuring export credits to lesser credits on country by country basis he said large lump political risk insurance is the sort of thing we want to take look at you have to try to look forward to see if you are simply in peak and trough situation or it is more long term thing stephens said in response to qustion about whether ecgd will strike more countries from its list of political risk insurance recipients he noted that certain countries have already been removed from the list

market loan could be pinned to trade bill sen david pryor ark said he was considering amending the senate finance committee trade bill with provision to require marketing loan for soybeans corn and wheat pryor told the futures industry association that there was great reluctance among members of the senate agriculture committee to reopen the 1985 farm bill and that marketing loan might have better chance in the finance panel the arkansas senator said the marketing loan which in effect allows producers to pay back their crop loans at the world price had led to 300 pct increase in cotton exports in 14 months and 72 pct increase in rice exports pryor serves on both the senate finance and agriculture committees

dutch official warns of more trade conflicts already strained relations between the and the european community ec are likely to get worse before they get better director general of the dutch economics ministry foreign affairs division frans engering said speaking at an american chamber of commerce lunch in the hague engering noted the developing history of crises over steel citrus and pasta and warned of more to come consider the strident tone of us declarations on airbus ill advised and the ec fats and oils tax proposal dangerous provocation he said feel that we shall probably have to deal with quite few more crises in the foreseeable future not only is the us congress clearly very determined to get the american balance of payments into better shape but the risks of brinkmanship are all the greater because the ec has its own constraints in meeting outside pressure engering noted if we ask ourselves whether it is perhaps inevitable that we keep pushing each other to the brink of actual trade war then think the answer is probably yes he said in order to reduce these tensions decision making in the ec must become less self centred and the us administration will have to exercise the authority to convince congress and pressure groups of the need for accommodation he added

treasury baker outlines trade bill criticisms treasury secretary james baker said that some of the trade bills proposed by congress conflict significantly with certain basic principles the reagan administration considers critical baker told senate committee that the administration would resist such measures as general import surcharge sector specific protection such as import quotas for individual products mandatory retaliation and limits on presidential discretion in negotiating more open markets abroad and other trade steps

colombia jan exports up but coffee values fall the value of colombian exports other than coffee rose 55 pct in january compared with the same period last year apparently setting trend for the trade balance in 1987 government statistics institute figures show they amounted to 180 mln dlrs fob compared with 147 mln dlrs for coffee drop of 42 pct from last year the trade balance registered 35 mln dlr surplus compared with 56 mln dlr surplus in january 1986 the national planning department forecast that in 1987 coffee colombia traditional major export will account for only one third of total exports or about billion dlrs

dealers say nakasone comment too late remarks by japan prime minister yasuhiro nakasone that last month meeting agreed to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen have come too late to influence currency trading dealers said after nakasone statement the dollar rose to 146 40 50 yen from an initial low of 144 20 40 and new york friday finish of 147 15 25 but the rebound was largely on short covering they said think nakasone desperate said bank foreign exchange manager nakasone told lower house budget committee in parliament that japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in paris last month to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen finance minister kiichi miyazawa told the same committee that the six britain canada france japan the and west germany had intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen his nakasone remarks should have been made and should have had bigger influence when the dollar was still above 150 yen said tam of morgan guaranty trust tam said the dollar has hit short term chart targets and is likely to rebound but he warned of another dip to below 145 yen dealers said the worsening trade relations between the and japan will continue to depress the dollar the trade issue has now become political issue since the reagan administration is facing uproar in congress over th3pygks in cutting the country 169 billion dlr trade deficit they said

miyazawa sees eventual lower trade deficit japanese finance minister kiichi miyazawa told press conference he expects the trade deficit to eventually start reflecting economic fundamentals which should influence exchange rates the minister was not referring to the trade data to be released in washington later today miyazawa also said he told major industrial nations when he was in washington last week that present exchange rates are not necessarily good he had said earlier in washington that current exchange rates were within levels implied in the february paris currency accord

german bank sees good soviet trade prospects soviet west german trade is expected to develop favourably due to moscow increasing openness to east west economic relations dresdner bank ag moscow representative michael stein said he told bank presentation the soviet union was last year hit by the fall in world oil prices which cut export revenue from oil related products and natural gas and its overseas buying power was also adversely affected by the lower dollar dresdner bank economist alfred apholte said the soviet union large currency and gold reserves had softened the impact of the dollar weakening and oil price drop

february trade to be reported on new basis the february monthly merchandise trade figures to be reported tuesday by the commerce department will be on new basis reflecting more recent data so avoiding future revisions of the monthly figure commerce officials said the overall january deficit of 14 billion dlrs will be revised but the february figure will be final one officials said previously the initial monthly figure has had to be revised in subsequent months because of the time lag between the report and the compiling of final estimates on imports and exports the reporting of the february trade data was delayed several weeks to permit gathering latest figures on imports and exports to give clearer picture of the monthly trade balance

april current account deficit narrows new zealand current account deficit narrowed to 76 mln dlrs in april from revised 89 mln dlrs in march and 224 mln dlrs in april 1986 in smoothed seasonally adjusted measurement the statistics department said the march figure was revised from 69 mln dlrs the department said in statement seasonally adjusted but non smoothed figures showed deficit of 99 mln dlrs against 76 mln dlrs in march and 230 mln dlrs in april 1986 totally unadjusted figures show deficit of 83 mln dlrs against 164 mln dlrs in march revised from 178 mln dlrs and compared with 262 mln in april 1986 the smoothed seasonally adjusted series shows surplus on merchandise trade of 145 mln dlrs against 135 mln dlrs in march and 30 mln dlrs in april 1986 seasonally adjusted but non smoothed figures show merchandise trade surplus of 132 mln dlrs against 148 mln dlr surplus in march and 14 mln dlr surplus in april 1986 unadjusted merchandise figures show surplus of 151 mln dlrs against mln dlr revised from 10 mln dlr deficit in march and 31 mln dlr deficit in march 1986 the smoothed seasonally adjusted deficit on invisibles was 234 mln dlrs against 236 mln dlrs in march and 255 in april 1986 the seasonally adjusted but non smoothed deficit on invisibles was 240 mln dlrs against 229 mln dlrs in march and 245 mln dlrs in april 1986 the unadjusted deficit on invisibles was 234 mln dlrs against 158 mln dlrs revised from 168 mln dlrs in march and 231 mln dlrs in april 1986 seasonally adjusted export and import figures were not available the department said these figures show continuing improvement in the current account deficit caused mainly by an improvement in the balance on merchandise trade which has now being in surplus since november 1985

economic spotlight polish sanctions poland says sanctions have cost its economy 15 billion dlrs and has made clear it wants washington to take lead in repairing the damage after lifting remaining restrictions two weeks ago polish officials are unable to provide precise breakdown of the figure saying it takes into account number of hypothetical losses some of them are too sophisticated to convert into financial terms one banking source said but western economic experts say the effect of sanctions is impossible to calculate they say it is blurred by the poor performance of poland economy and dismiss the 15 billion dlr figure as illusory sanctions have provided very useful excuse for under achieving they did have bad effect yes but they only contributed to largely internal economic problems one said the imposed the measures and withdrew most favoured nation mfn trading status from poland in 1982 in retaliation for suppression of the solidarity free trade union under martial law the estimated cost to the polish economy was originally devised several years ago by the institute of national economy an offshoot of the central planning commission according to one western envoy an expert on polish economic affairs it extrapolated 1979 information on growth trends in trade with the united states as well as increases in credits from western commercial and government lenders but the calculations were based on time when trade was booming and credits still flowed freely he said dismissing the estimate as theoretical projection based on high point which has no real scientific evaluation foreign trade ministry official said polish exports to the in the late 1970s averaged around 400 mln dlrs annually and had fallen by half since the sanctions were imposed imports have suffered slumping from around 800 mln dlrs to 200 mln as credits ran out poland has dwindling trade surplus with the west last year it was one billion dlrs against targeted billion official figures show acknowledging that sanctions have lost poland important markets including agricultural equipment textiles chemicals and some foodstuffs western economists say credits dried up for economic not political reasons poland is accusing the west of letting economic relations deteriorate for political reasons said one expert it an illusion based on misunderstanding of western economy there limit to how much you can go on giving someone who has no hope of repaying it another said adding that poland had benefited from global phenomenon of easy credits in the 1970s which were no longer today reality describing the 15 billion dlr assessment as nebulous one diplomat said it also included losses of hypothetical orders and setbacks to polish research through the curbing of scientific links and exchanges western officials say the lifting of sanctions and new mfn status will have little impact on poland which has hard currency debt of 33 billion dlrs and lacks the means to modernise its industry mfn doesn really mean anything only that poland will not be treated worse than other countries it will be difficult to regain access to the market because different forces are in play now said one western envoy he said polish products were not competitive and their quality was too low trade wars and possible protectionist measures amongst the japan and europe would also hamper poland efforts to regain entry deputy foreign trade minister janusz kaczurba recognised this fact recently kaczurba told the official pap news agency recently making up our lost position will take long time and be uncommonly difficult and in certain cases impossible in period of two to three years it will be possible to increase the level of exports by only about 100 mln dlrs while poland is unlikely to seek compensation it says it has moral right to assistance from the which it says imposed the sanctions illegally but western economist said the argument that sanctions were unilateral torpedoing of the polish economy won cut any ice the americans will just reply that the poles acted immorally in crushing solidarity nevertheless polish national bank head wladyslaw baka in talks in washington last week with the international monetary fund imf and world bank made it clear that poland was looking for lead from the united states he was quoted by pap as saying that poland would meet its financial obligations to the united states but not in short time and not without cooperative stand on the part of its foreign economic partners he stressed that the had particular opportunity to play part in the cooperative policy of poland partners interested in the settlement of polish debt putting it more sharply one senior banking official blamed washington for obstructing talks with the world bank imf and paris club of western creditor governments in recent years and said it should now play more positive role as major superpower the united states can influence international organisations he said citing recent meetings aimed at stabilising currencies as an example of the extent to which western nations were prepared to cooperate

taiwan plans new tariff cuts taiwan plans another round of deep tariff cuts this year to help narrow its trade surplus with the senior economic planner said wang chao ming vice chairman of the council for economic planning and development told reuters taiwan would further reduce import tariffs on 700 products sometime in the second half of this year cuts of up to 50 pct on those items were made last year and wang said further cuts would go much deeper we have to speed up liberalisation and cut import tariffs faster and more substantially he said the united states taiwan main trading partner has said the island import tariffs still ranging from high of almost 60 pct were unacceptable it has criticised the cuts as too selective taiwan trade surplus with the united states hit 13 billion dlrs last year the surplus has boosted foreign exchange reserves to 50 billion dlrs which wang said made taiwan target for protectionism wang said the trade surplus and the reserves weakened taiwan position in talks with washington over export quotas particularly for shoes textiles and machine tools which are among the island main export earners special taiwanese trade delegation leaves for washington tomorrow to try to renegotiate an agreement signed last year limiting exports of taiwan textiles under the accord taiwan textile export growth was limited to pct each year until 1988 taipei has said it is losing markets to south korea and hong kong which were given more generous terms reuter

talks show new canadian confidence group says canada decision to raise the issue of free trade pact with the was sign of what many see as new spirit of canadian self confidence public policy study group said it suggests the canada of the immediate post war period when it was major player in the process of building postwar world the washington based atlantic council said and canadian negotiators opened talks last summer aimed at dismantling trade barriers between the two countries the world biggest trading partners with crossborder shipments of about 150 billion dlrs annually the council study said the trade talks with deadline of october for an agreement are the biggest issue in canadian relations the study said liberalized trade between the two countries would improve the competitiveness of their economies in world markets and lessen trade irritants which now mar their ties the council said in the past most canadians have shied away from the notion of free trade arrangement fearing to be overwhelmed economically and politically by closer association with country 10 times their size in population but at the same time it added canadians realized their domestic market was too small to permit the mass production and sales needed to raise productivity to the level demanded by an increasingly competitive world the council said that in the talks canada is chiefly interested in minimizing the imposing of duties against allegedly subsidized exports recent example was the 15 per cent duty the imposed on canadian lumber exports on grounds the shipments were being subsidized the council said the chief concerns included ending curbs against banking insurance telecommunications and the so called cultural industries publishing broadcasting and films it said other major canadian issues were defense cooperation acid rain and the rejection of canadian assertion of sovereignty over waters of the northwest passage

tokyo bids to stop chip row becoming trade war japan is seeking to prevent its computer chips dispute with the from erupting into full scale trade war government officials said we hope that the dispute on this specific issue won have an adverse effect on our overall relationship with the united states ministry of international trade and industry miti official said on friday washington announced plans for as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on japanese electronic goods for tokyo alleged failure to live up to bilateral computer chip pact that agreement reached last year after heated negotiations called on japan to stop selling cut price chips in world markets and to buy more american made semiconductors foreign ministry officials immediately tried to isolate the fall out from the dispute by seeking to separate it from prime minister yasuhiro nakasone planned trip to washington at the end of april while japan has already done about all it can to make sure the chip pact is working the government is studying measures it can take in other fields to defuse american anger and ensure the trip success they said the perception of japan in the congress is very bad one official told reuters we would very much like to do something to respond to that in an apparent effort to prevent the chip dispute from spreading to other areas miti officials sought to depict the action as severe warning to japanese semiconductor makers not to the government faced with belligerent domestic chip industry and an angry american congress the japanese government has been forced to walk an increasingly fine line in the semiconductor dispute trade analysts said they said that it was an open secret that japan largest chip maker nec corp was not happy with what it viewed as the draconian measures miti was taking to implement the pact included enforced production cuts the angry response of japanese chip makers yesterday to the announcement of the tariffs highlighted the difficulties the government faces in taking further action japanese semiconductor manufacturers have complied with the japan agreement said shoichi saba chairman of the electronic industries association of japan he accused the of being irrational he said the action had made the bilateral chip pact meaningless saba comments contrasted with those of prime minister yasuhiro nakasone who said tokyo wanted to solve the dispute through consultations japan is expected to send high level official to washington early next month to try to convince the not to go ahead with the tariffs on april 17 trade analysts say tokyo is likely to outline industry plans to step up purchases of chips and to propose joint investigation into allegations of chip dumping

baldrige warns of world trade war danger commerce secretary malcolm baldrige predicted congress will pass reasonable trade bill this year and said tough protectionist legislation could prompt trade war the mood of the congress right now is as tough on trade as ve ever seen it in six years in washington baldrige said in television interview think we ll still be able to get reasonable trade bill out in spite of that because the whole congress is trying to work together with the administration but there is hardening trade attitude he said president reagan opposes protectionist legislation but agreed to support trade bill when it became apparent that opposition democrats would pass such legislation however baldrige warned measures that would penalise trading partners such as japan south korea and taiwan for failing to cut their trade surpluses with the could lead to retaliation and he said he would urge reagan to veto any such bill when asked if there is rising danger of worldwide trade war baldrige said yes don think there any question about that

german february import prices fall import prices in west germany fell pct in february from january to stand 15 pct below their level in february 1986 the federal statistics office said in january the import price index base 1980 was unchanged compared with december but 17 pct lower against january 1986 february export prices same base as import prices were unchanged compared with january and pct lower than in february 1986 in january export prices fell pct against december to stand pct lower than in january 1986

european community to set up office in peking china and the european community ec signed an agreement on the establishment of an ec office here chinese vice foreign minister zhou nan and the ec external relations commissioner willy de clercq signed the accord ec sources said the office was likely to open in the second half of this year in 1986 the ec was china third largest trading partner with chinese imports from the ec worth billion dlrs and exports worth billion dlrs de clercq told the official china daily that more joint ventures should be set up in china as way of reducing china trade deficit with the ec the ec affairs in china are currently looked after by whichever country holds the group six monthly rotating presidency now held by the belgians until the danes take over in july

gatt to debate charges of airbus subsidies the will pursue its complaint that european governments unfairly subsidise the airbus industrie aircraft consortium in proceedings at the gatt civil aircraft committee gatt spokesman said today the presented its case for the first time to the aircraft committee of the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt during special two day session ending today gatt rules cover some 80 pct of world commerce the 20 member committee agreed to open debate on the complaint starting with informal consultations and then holding special session in july trade officials said the tension has eased the permanent trade ambassador of the 12 member european community tran van thinh told reporters the has decided to go through proper channels trade officials again made clear their anger over what they call unfair government support for airbus voiced during visit to european capitals in february in letter calling for the special committee meeting washington charged france west germany the spain and the ec commission with unfair practices on behalf of airbus the charges that the europeans are violating rules laid down in the 1979 agreement on trade in civil aircraft washington presented its reading of rules on inducement to purchase aircraft and support for development of airlines during the special session and asked the committee to confirm its view official sources in the delegations said the views would be considered during the informal consultations but the europeans would also be free to bring up any complaints against american civil aircraft practices some delegates said the position appeared to give such broad interpretation to the rules as to suggest that the civil aircraft accord needed re negotiating all these matters would be considered during the informal meetings

senate wants japan semiconducter pact enforced the senate has unanimously called for president reagan immediately to force japan to live up to pledge to stop dumping its microchips and open its markets to chipmakers the senate voted 93 to to urge reagan to impose penalties on japanese high technology products containing semiconductors in retaliation for what it sees as japan violations of the semiconductor pact while the measure does not bind reagan to any action senate leaders said its adoption would warn japan stiffer legislation would be considered if the violations continue we want to send message to japan to let it know how the senate feels about this matter senate democratic leader robert byrd told the senate senate finance committee chairman lloyd bentsen told the senate the measure was not aimed at retaliation but at correcting japan unfair trade practices key house trade lawmaker representative richard gephardt also announced he would seek to force japan and other countries with huge trade surpluses to slash their surplus by 10 pct year for three years

baker sees 15 to 20 billion dlr drop in trade gap treasury secretary james baker said he expected the trade deficit to fall by 15 billion to 20 billion dlrs in 1987 commenting on the deficit during an interview on cable news network baker said think you re going to see 15 to 20 billion dlr reduction this year the deficit was 170 billion dlrs in 1986 baker noted that the benefits of weaker currency take 12 to 18 months to affect the trade balance and said it is now 18 months since the plaza agreement to lower the dollar value

gatt sets up dispute panel on canadian herring the ruling gatt council set up formal dispute panel to examine complaint that canadian law prohibiting export of unprocessed herring and salmon was discriminatory david wood official spokesman of the general agreement on tariffs and trade gatt told news briefing the decision was taken after bilateral consultations failed to resolve the row ambassador michael samuels charged during the council debate that canada was trying to preserve domestic jobs by insisting that herring and salmon be processed at home robert white canada deputy chief of delegation replied the law was in line with gatt rules and was for conservations reasons but he agreed to setting up the dispute panel

canada february trade surplus billion dlrs canada had trade surplus of 25 billion dlrs in february compared with an upward revised 623 mln dlrs surplus in january statistics canada said the january surplus originally was reported at 533 mln dlrs the february surplus last year was 189 mln dlrs february exports seasonally adjusted were 10 44 billion dlrs against 85 billion in january and 10 05 billion in february 1986 february imports were 19 billion dlrs against 23 billion in january and 86 billion in february 1986
reagan renews anti protectionism stand white house says trade war unlikely

economic spotlight japan pushes its chipmakers japanese microchip makers are being strong armed into compliance with japan pact on semiconductors halting predatory pricing and opening japan market to foreign chips industry analysts said but doubts remain over whether the ministry of international trade and industry miti which is pressuring the firms can successfully battle market forces and whether the industry is geared up to take advantage of any breathing space they said threats to scrap the agreement signed last september have pushed miti to try harder to get recalcitrant japanese chipmakers to abide by the pact the analysts said miti has been moving hot and heavy throughout the industry to get things done said bache securities japan associate vice president peter wolffe last month miti told chipmakers to cut production for the january to march period by 10 pct to help dry up inexpensive chips that have escaped from japan to grey markets not subject to the pact price controls the ministry also asked electronics firms to provide distributors with certificates designating them as authorised exporters in an effort to close loopholes through which grey marketeers sneak chips out of japan market analysts said trade negotiators here last week said the pact was in jeopardy because of continued dumping in non american markets and little sign of increased foreign sales in japan but major japanese firms appear to have agreed to the production cuts several analysts said last week nec corp said it would cut production in line with miti request nec has been the most aggressive in resisting miti demands said david keller analyst at james capel and co once nec cuts production it means they all have still pressures remain to keep production high japanese firms need high output to cut unit prices for sales that the commerce department assigns them under the pact the best way to lower cost is to produce more said salomon brothers asia ltd analyst carole ryavec preparations for possible upturn in demand could also spur higher production next quarter merrill lynch analyst matt aizawa said grey marketeers may also be able to outfox any new restrictions some industry officials said it like tax avoidance schemes said steve donovan head of mmi japan as soon as you close one route another opens miti pressure has annoyed some makers who had earlier shrugged off miti guidance it getting to be like communism said one but analysts said output cuts could help by making it easier to increase prices as planned on april and forcing firms to stop extending market share by selling at loss they re going to have to start running their businesses like businesses bache wolffe said miti has also been conducting highly public campaign urging chip users to buy foreign made chips but industry officials said response has been mixed at best there has been some change but it not across the board said one spokesman the companies have varying degree of urgency the ultimate impact of all these efforts by miti on the troubled industry remains in doubt analysts added pressure to cut production of 256 kilobit dram dynamic random access memory chips could merely speed the transition to one megabit chips where japan now leads analysts said whether firms are able to stage comeback in memory chips or interested in doing so also remains unclear they said analysts are watching with interest the fate of new consortium which hopes to challenge japan by developing the most advanced technology for microchip manufacturing even in the thorny area of access much depends on commitment as well as on japanese openness some said the sia semiconductor industry association doesn even have an office here source close to the industry said you could question just how committed they are in addition some industry analysts question the effectiveness of bilateral agreement that leaves out third country chipmakers such as those in south korea south korea gaining market share said one analyst they re the real winners from the agreement

canada vows to fight potash action external affairs minister joe clark today vowed to do everything possible to fight the action against canadian potash exports but also warned against raising the alarm too early in the dispute in the latest flashpoint in canadian trade relations the international trade commission ruled unanimously monday that canadian potash shipments valued at 270 million dlrs last year were injuring the industry we certainly intend to do everything we can to insure that canadian interests are well protected clark told the house of commons in the daily question period but he said the opposition parties should be careful not to raise false alarms too early the case now goes before the commerce department trade division to determine if duty should be imposed potash producers from new mexico claiming unfair government subsidies are seeking 43 pct tariff on canada shipments canada the world largest potash producer exported mln metric tonnes of potash last year with nearly third going to the most of the potash used in the production of fertilizer comes from provincially owned mines in saskatchewan in the commons liberal member lloyd axworthy branded the ruling as just another trade harrassment from the and criticized clark assurances the country interests would be protected we received exactly the same kind of assurances in the softwood lumber case that was totally fumbled and bumbled axworthy said canada progressive conservative government agreed to impose 15 pct duty on its softwood lumber exports earlier this year to end long and bitter bilateral trade dispute with the axworthy urged the government to present canada case to world trade authorities under the general agreement on tariffs and trade but clark maintained the potash dispute was another example of why canada needs to find new way to settle bilateral irritants in the free trade negotiations under way with the what we are seeking to do is put in place better system clark said meanwhile saskatchewan trade minister bob andrew expressed confidence canada would win its case claiming the problem stems from low international commodity prices and not government subsidies the reality of the problem and the injury is caused worldwide he said it caused by downturn in the commodity price for fertilizer whether it potash fertilizer nitrogen fertilizer or whatever

february jobs gains show stronger economy momentum in th economy may be picking up given solid across the board increases in the february employment report economists said non farm payroll employment rose 337 000 in february twice what the financial markets expected this follows 319 000 gain in january revised down from previously reported 448 000 increase even if you look at january and february together this is still much stronger report than the consensus expectation in the market said allan leslie of discount corporation economists stressed that gains in hours worked signal much larger gains in february production and income than previously forecast the average work week rose hours to 35 hours from 34 hours in january the average manufacturing work week rose hours to 41 hours the longest factory work week since november 1966 the commerce department said the gains in manufacturing employment point to very large increase in industrial production of between and pct said joe carson of chemical bank this compares to pct gain in january industrial production peter greenbaum of smith barney harris upham and co inc noted that the average wage rate increased to 87 dlrs an hour in february from 83 dlrs in january combined with the increase in hours worked this means we ll get pretty healthy gain in personal income vis vis the wage and salary disbursement he said greenbaum said that february personal income should rise at least pct after being flat in january he said the february employment gains are consistent with his firm first quarter real gross national product growth forecast of pct economists agreed that the employment data were negative for the credit markets in that they signal healthier economy and no easing in the federal reserve monetary policy but most said that the market need not fear tighter policy either this report is another reason for the fed to not consider easing said ray stone of merrill lynch capital markets inc it gives them more room to address the dollar situation he said if they had to nudge policy tighter they could do so but it most likely they ll sit and wait the data have not been uniform stone added durable goods were weak in january and now employment is strong in january durable goods orders dropped pct followed by pct drop in factory goods orders retail sales fell pct and the merchandise trade gap widened to 14 billion dlrs things just aren adding up said steve slifer of lehman goverment securities inc consumer spending capital spending goverment spending and net exports data show very weak first quarter gnp growth of one pct he said the employment and production data point to big inventory build up but that what we thought in the fourth quarter and we only got pct gnp growth manufacturing employment gained 50 000 after falling 15 000 in january economists estimated that 30 000 of the gain was accounted for by striking workers in the steel and machinery industries returning to work even so some economists said that the manufacturing gains have resulted from an improving trade outlook jason benderly of goldman sachs and co noted that the trade picture improved in the fourth quarter as net exports grew at 20 pct annual rate while the rate of increase in imports fell to only six pct and that it continues to improve in the first quarter not only the official statistics for the fourth quarter but evidence of pick up in orders from overseas for paper products chemicals high tech goods and capital goods show that trade is improving benderley said the economy is moving between extremes he said some reports are going to look bad and some good but first quarter gnp is going to grow in the middle at about three pct 287 000 gain in services employment comprised the greater part of february employment gain retail services employment rose 129 000 in february compared to gain of 117 000 in january previously reported at 166 000 construction employment rose slim 000 in february but this follows robust 113 000 gain in january revised down from previously reported 142 000 gain the civilian unemployment rate was unchanged in february at pct this means the jobless rate has stayed at pct for three consecutive months the lowest reading since march 1980 the commerce department noted the federal reserve has to be pleased with this report carson said this takes away the fed flexibility to ease but there no reason to tighten it way too early for that

wine exports rose 15 per cent last year exports of american wine rose 14 per cent last year to total of million gallons the wine institute said the san francisco based promotional group said 95 per cent of the exported wine was from california and the top three markets were canada japan and britain japan which edged out britain as the leading importer of american wines in 1985 continued in second place canadian imports rose per cent to million gallons japan per cent to million gallons and britain 20 per cent to 962 360 gallons spokesman for the institute said the declining value of the dollar and strong promotional efforts on the part of the california wine industry contributed significantly to the increased shipments the 1986 wine exports were valued at 34 mln dlrs up from 27 mln dlrs the previous year

fed heller urges japanese to buy goods member of the federal reserve board robert heller said he wanted to see stronger japanese demand for american goods what was advocating here was more japanese purchases of american goods heller said in response to question about the dollar weakness in currency markets he told heritage foundation forum be very happy to see that in his formal remarks heller said he supported the idea of using commodity prices as an indicator for monetary policy asked if he would raise the issue at the next federal open market committee meeting he said even at previous meetings commodity prices were raised he added would not expect future meetings to be different from past meetings in that respect

usx lt chairman calls for lower dollar usx corp chairman david roderick called for lower value for the dollar against other currencies to help speed correction in the trade deficit which last year reached 170 billion dlrs in remarks prepared for speech before the economic club of detroit roderick said there should be total resolve that the dollar versus other major currencies as well as the currencies of other nations having substantial trade surplus with us must continue to decline so that the correction in our trade deficit starts on the road to recovery roderick said the should be understanding of the economic pain our trading partners experience as result of falling dollar but he added as painful as the correction may be to our trading partners it is less painful than leaving the problem uncorrected because that would lead us into an inevitable lengthy and steep world recession roderick said between february 1985 and december 1986 the dollar fell by more than 40 pct in real terms against major industrial currencies and by 30 to 35 pct against broader group of currencies of nearly all developing nations at the end of 1986 he said the value of foreign assets in the exceeded the value of assets abroad by 240 billion dlrs compared to five years ago when the had surplus in assets of 141 billion company spokesman said the data were provided by economic consultants to usx the primary reason for the trade imbalance was the 70 pct rise of the dollar between 1980 and 1985 although other factors were involved roderick said but it is wrong he said to attribute the massive trade deficit to fundmental deterioration of productivity or of american product quality these areas need to be improved but they are not the root cause of the trade gap problem roderick said he urged american manufacturers to become more competitive so they can compete in global markets in the speech the usx chairman also called for changes in securities laws to curb what he called abuses by corporate raiders and speculators among his proposals which he presented to the senate banking committee in testimony last week were requirement that raiders give 24 hour notice for every one pct of stock they acquire in company roderick proposed that tender offers must be made for all cash to all stockholders on equal terms and that raiders be required to have financing in place before tender is made further raiders should be required to make an all cash tender offer once they acquire 10 pct of target company stock he said and payment of greenmail or preferential price by target company to buy back raider stake should be prohibited under the revised laws roderick said changes were necessary to curb abuses but that he did not want laws that would hurt the financial markets or discourage fair price to all takeovers

canada january trade surplus 533 mln dlrs canada had trade surplus of 533 mln dlrs in january compared with an upward revised 965 mln dlrs surplus in december statistics canada said the december surplus originally was reported at 964 mln dlrs the january surplus last year was 19 billion dlrs january exports seasonally adjusted were 72 billion dlrs against 10 39 billion in december and 10 89 billion in january 1986 january imports were 19 billion dlrs against 43 billion in december and 71 billion in january 1986

seoul announces more tariff cuts for south korea will cut import taxes on 50 items including construction equipment photographic film cigarettes and pipe tobacco to help reduce its trade surplus with the united states the finance ministry said the tariff cuts of between five and 30 percentage points take effect on july this brings to 157 the number of goods on which import taxes have been cut this year ministry official said the 157 are among about 290 items on which washington has asked seoul to lower tariffs he added today announcement follows saturday removal of import curbs on 170 products for 46 of those products the had had sought free access to the south korean market this is in line with the government policy to limit our trade surplus with the united states to help reduce trade friction between the two countries the official said south korea trade surplus with the rose to billion dlrs in 1986 from billion in 1985 officials said the surplus was expected to widen further in 1987 but seoul would try to hold it below eight billion dlrs the finance ministry said tariffs would be cut later this month on further 53 items including acrylic yarn and ethylene by an average percentage points in order to check inflation the officials said the tariff cuts would contribute to holding wholesale and consumer price rises at less than three pct this year

soviet economist sees few 1987 gains in trade there is little chance soviet exports to the united states will rise in 1987 but moscow current trade reforms should result in more trade in manufactured goods in future soviet economist said sergey frolov chief economist at amtorg trading corp an agent for soviet trade organisations and industries told ussr business meeting the soviet union produces few items that western nations want but reforms including upgrading the quality of goods and allowing joint ventures with foreign firms will encourage modest export gains in future frolov said the soviet union exported 500 mln dlrs worth of goods to the united states in 1986 and imported billion dlrs worth he gave no trade forecast for 1987 but he said that even if all obstacles were removed total trade between the two countries would remain between two and three billion dlrs year the post detente embargoes have taught the ussr to limit its trading with the he said

britain warns japan over trade row british corporate affairs minister michael howard told japan to resolve the row over the firm cable and wireless plc lt cawl shareholding in new japanese telecommunications company or face an abrupt deterioration in trade relations in meetings with both the foreign and telecommunications ministers howard said he expressed deep concern about the way tokyo had handled the dispute and about the continuing trade imbalance between the two countries put it to the post and telecommunications minister that was sure he did not want to be responsible for an abrupt deterioration in the trading relations of our countries which would have widespread reverberations elsewhere in the world howard told reporters he listened very carefully and have little doubt the message got home he added british frustration over the lopsided trade balance nearly six billion dlrs in japan favour last year has reached boiling point over the telecommunications issue howard said howard has accused japan of trying to shut out cable and wireless from having major role in the international telephone market in japan want fair crack of the whip for cable and wireless as want fair crack of the whip for britain generally in trading relations howard said we simply aren prepared to continue to accept the imbalance which has been the position for such long time post and telecommunications ministry officials were unable to comment on howard meeting with their minister but foreign ministry officials said foreign minister tadashi kuranari said that british exports to japan are increasing but acknowledged the continuing imbalance in trade kuranari said he wants everyone in the telecommunications dispute including cable and wireless to be satisfied howard told reporters that britain was actively considering possible retaliatory measures if it did not get its way on the telecommunications issue there are measures which are under consideration if we continue to suffer from the imbalance in our trading relations he added but gave no details he said he had received reassuring response from the japanese he has spoken with but of course we ve had reassuring signs from the japanese for quite some time he added what ve made plain is we expect to see action howard ruled out using powers in britain financial services bill to retaliate against unfair trade practices those powers which allow london to ban foreign financial firms like banks from britain are designed to ensure firms equal access to overseas financial markets

turkey sees billion dlr deficit in 1986 turkey expects 1986 balance of payments deficit of billion dlrs well over target but is taking steps to improve its performance in this and other fields ali tigrel director of economic planning at the state planning organisation said he told reuters the shortfall was direct consequence of economic growth of nearly eight pct up from pct in 1985 which he said resulted mostly from surge in domestic demand tigrel acknowledged need to cut inflation further after drop of more than 12 points to 24 pct in the treasury wholesale index last year this year target of 20 pct might be attainable but the economic management will have to be careful he said tigrel whose department produces the annual programme which is central to the government economic planning said turkey creditworthiness was at risk over the current account shortfall originally targeted at 695 mln dlrs we must alleviate the current account substantially to sustain the creditworthiness that we have managed to secure over the last five years he added his comment echoed last october organisation for economic cooperation and development report on turkey which said ankara case for more medium term financing on better terms would look better if inflation were lower and the current account deficit cut or turned into surplus in 1987 we must reduce the rate of growth in public sector investments we must reduce the public sector deficit as percentage of gnp and we must achieve very visible improvement in the current account deficit he said tigrel said surge in public sector spending last year was also to blame for the high deficits appropriations to government departments had been cut by eight pct since the budget was passed in december and foreign borrowing by municipalities had been restrained we are trying make sure that public bodies stick to the investment programme and do not exceed their appropriations he said it was hoped to bring the public sector borrowing requirement down to five pct of gnp in 1987 from an estimated pct in 1986 more modest gnp growth of five pct for 1987 was also targeted tigrel said measures were being taken to encourage exports and production incentives were being considered we must try to make sure that more capacity is injected into the turkish economy in the coming years the promotion policy is geared to make sure that both foreign investment and local private capital come more into play as far as manufacturing capacity is concerned tigrel said he said the process of structural adjustment of the turkish economy to free market policies begun in 1980 was still under way trade had been liberalised and freer exchange rate policy applied but he acknowledged there was more to be done in country where the state still dominates industry and the currency is only partially convertible

japan not in trade war yeutter says the united states and japan are not involved in trade war despite sanctions announced last week against japanese semiconductors trade representative clayton yeutter said in my judgement we re not even close to trade war yeutter told house agriculture committee hearing yeutter said if japan takes action to honor its agreement with the on semiconductor trade then the retaliatory response will last relatively short period yeutter said japan must stop dumping chips in third countries and buy more american computer chips

nakasone intervenes in microchip dispute with prime minister yasuhiro nakasone intervened to try to resolve japan escalating dispute with the over semiconductor trade government officials said at today cabinet meeting nakasone told trade and industry minister hajime tamura to redouble his efforts to calm anger over what it sees as japan unfair trade practices in semiconductors nakasone intervened only two days before scheduled meeting of the reagan administration economic policy council to consider whether japan is reneging on its microchip pact with the that pact agreed last year after months of negotiations calls on japan to stop selling cut price chips in world markets and to raise its imports of semiconductors senior officials have accused tokyo of failing to live up to the accord and have threatened retaliatory action yesterday tamura ministry of international trade and industry miti launched last ditch attempt to salvage the pact by writing letters to policy makers setting out japan case and telling japanese chip makers to cut output in his letter the contents of which were released today tamura said miti survey carried out at the beginning of march showed japanese producers were not selling at cut rate prices in asian markets in separate letter sent to senior officials miti vice minister for international affairs makoto kuroda suggested the two countries could conduct joint investigation into allegations of japanese chip dumping in such markets

french 1986 current account surplus revised the french 1986 current account balance of payments surplus has been revised slightly upwards to 25 billion francs from the 25 billion franc figure announced last month the finance ministry said this compares with billion deficit in 1985 and while it is the first surplus since 1979 is substantially lower than the 50 billion surplus forecast by the previous socialist government before they lost office in march last year net long term capital outflows rose sharply to 70 billion francs last year from billion in 1985 largely due to major program of foreign debt repayment the ministry said in the fourth quarter alone the unadjusted surplus rose to 14 billion francs from billion the previous quarter but the adjusted surplus fell to billion from billion fourth quarter medium and long term foreign debt repayments exceeded new credits by 11 billion francs

fed chairman volcker says bank proposals worry the chairman of the federal reserve board paul volcker has written to the chairman of the house banking committee to raise concerns about legislative proposals scheduled for consideration wednesday volcker told committee chairman fernand st germain proposal to deny primary dealer status to firms from countries that do not grant firms equal access to their government debt markets might invite retaliation against firms abroad he added even japan against whom this proposal seems to be particularly directed has started opening its markets in his letter made available at the treasury volcker also said proposal to ease debt problems of developing countries by setting up public facility to buy their debts owed to commercial banks was problem believe that the prospect of debt relief would undermine the difficult internal efforts of the borrowing countries to achieve the structural reform that is needed regardless of the policies that are followed on servicing external debt volcker said it might also cause private lenders to become reluctant to extend more credit to the borrowing countries he said volcker said he endorsed comments by treasury secretary james baker about the inappropriateness of using public resources for purchasing private commercial bank debt which we both see as an inherent aspect of the proposed international debt facility he also said proposal for establishing formal procedures for international negotiations on currency exchange rates is unrealistic and could well have damaging effects for example the bill directive to intitiate negotiations in order to achieve competitive exchange rate for the dollar matter upon which there can be considerable difference among analysts runs the risk of building up potentially destabilizing market expectations volcker said he recommended we should not lock ourselves into formalized procedures for international negotiations on exchange rates but instead use other more flexible means like the recent mmeting in paris between treasury and central bank representatives and those of major trade allies

sweden sets october deadline for africa boycott sweden announced its promised program of unilateral economic sanctions against south africa and gave firms an october deadline to cut trading links foreign trade minister anita gradin said trade boycott of south africa and neighbouring namibia would take effect from july followed by three month period of grace to give companies time to wind down their operations from october no direct trade would be allowed in either direction with certain exceptions covering medical supplies and printed matter gradin told news conference she said exceptions would also be granted in cases where swedish trade boycott would benefit south african firms and disadvantage south africa black ruled neighbours the front line states gradin cautioned that legislation upon which the boycott would be based was not impossible to get round she said parliamentary committee would investigate ways of closing some of the bigger loopholes including indirect trade with south africa via swedish subsidiaries in third countries

asks japan end agriculture import controls the wants japan to eliminate import controls on agricultural products within three years visiting under secretary of state for economic affairs allen wallis told eishiro saito chairman of the federation of economic organisations keidanren spokesman for keidanren said the spokesman quoted wallis as saying drastic measures would be needed to stave off protectionist legislation by congress wallis who is attending sub cabinet level bilateral trade meeting made the remark yesterday in talks with saito wallis was quoted as saying the reagan administration wants japanese cooperation so the white house can ensure any trade bill is moderate one rather than containing retaliatory measures or antagonising any particular country he was also quoted as saying the would be pleased were japan to halve restrictions on agricultural imports within five years if the country cannot cope with abolition within three the spokesman said japan currently restricts imports of 22 agricultural products ban on rice imports triggered recent complaints about japan agricultural policy

economic spotlight congress raps japan the congress is making japan with its enormous worldwide trade surplus the symbol of the trade crisis and the focus of its efforts to turn around america record trade deficit japan has come to symbolize what we fear most in trade the challenge to our high technology industries the threat of government nutured competition and the multitude of barriers to our exports senate democratic leader robert byrd said if we can find way to come to terms with japan over trade problems we can manage our difficulties with other countries the west virginia democrat said at senate finance committee hearing on the trade bill byrd and house speaker jim wright texas democrat have made trade legislation priority this year and wide ranging bill is being readied for probable house approval next month japan bilateral trade surplus jumped from 12 billion dlrs in 1980 to 62 billion dlrs last year its surplus rose to 14 billion dlrs in february from billion dlrs in january congress points to the record 169 billion dlrs trade deficit in 1986 and the slow response in the trade imbalance to the dollar decline in world currency markets as reason to press japan to buy more goods they are particularly dismayed by the rapid deterioration in exports of sophisticated computer technology in response to the growing anger and pressure by the semiconductor industry president reagan friday announced he intended to raise tariffs as much as 300 mln dlrs on japanese electronic goods in retaliation for japan failure to abide by 1986 japanese semiconductor agreement congress also has been been angered by the administration lack of success with japan on host of other trade issues including beef citrus automobile parts telecommunications goods and financial services the bulk of the house trade bill was written last week in four committees it is package of trade sanctions and measures to force the administration take tough action against foreign trade barriers and unfair competition although most provisions do not single out japan in many cases their impact would be to restrict imports of japanese products or make them more expensive with higher duties the cornerstone of the trade legislation passed the house ways and means committee by vote of 34 to its focus is to force president reagan to retaliate against unfair foreign competition and to make it easier for industries to win temporary relief from surges in imports the most controversial issue an amendment to restrict imports if countries such as japan with large surpluses do not buy more goods was left for an april vote by the house rep richard gephardt democratic presidential aspirant from missouri has the support of wright and other key democrats to press for passage of the amendment the measure would have the most impact on japan west germany taiwan and south korea if japan for example does not reduce its barriers by mid 1988 the united states would set import quotas or tariffs to cut japanese surplus by ten per cent year for three years tired of going into companies and having managers say to me we re not over competing in japan because we can compete in the marketplace that argument needs to be taken away from american business gephardt said the administration has said it could not support trade bill containing such provision

taiwan announces new round of import tariff cuts taiwan announced plans for another round of import tariff cuts on 862 foreign goods shortly before trade talks with washington which officials described as move to help balance trade with the united states wang der hwa deputy director of the finance ministry customs administration department told reporters the list of products included 60 items asked by washington the move is part of our government efforts to encourage imports from our trading partners particularly from the united states he said he said the ministry sent proposal today to the cabinet that the tariffs on such products as cosmetics bicycles apples radios garments soybeans and television sets be cut by between five and 50 pct the cabinet was expected to give its approval next thursday and the new tariff cuts would be implemented possibly starting on april 20 he added taiwan introduced sweeping tariff cut on some 700 foreign products last january aimed at helping reduce its growing trade surplus with the united states the island largest trading partner washington however was not satisfied with the cuts and pressed for more reductions as way of cutting its huge trade deficit with taipei washington deficit with taipei rose to record 13 billion dlrs last year from 10 billion in 1985 it widened to 61 billion in the first quarter of 1987 from 78 billion year earlier taiwan official figures show today announcement came before departure later today of 15 member taiwan delegation for washington for series of trade talks with officials the delegation leader vincent siew told reporters last night he was leaving with heavy heart meaning that he would face tough talks in washington because of rising protectionist sentiments in the congress taiwan 1986 trade surplus with washington was the third largest after japan and canada siew said the talks starting on april 14 would cover calls for taiwan to open its market to american products purchases of major machinery and power plant equipment import tariff cuts and protection of intellectual property am afraid this time we have to give more than take from our talks with the he said without elaborating

hungarian economy continues unfavourable trend hungary economy and hard currency trade have failed so far this year to reverse two year unfavourable trend the official hungarian news agency mti said industrial production in january and february was only pct up on the same 1986 period mti said while hard currency exports fell six pct as imports rose 10 pct hungary hard currency trade fell into deficit of 539 mln dlrs last year from surplus of 295 mln in 1985 and billion in 1984 mti quoted government spokesman saying last december wage freeze decree would expire on april as envisaged gross domestic product grew sluggish one pct in 1986 after stagnating in 1985 and growing pct in 1984

envoy advises nakasone to prepare for visit the japanese ambassador to the suggested that prime minister yasuhiro nakasone make efforts to present advanced proposals on trade issues when he visits washington next month ambassador nobuo matsunaga made the recommendation at meeting with nakasone kyodo news service said matsunaga also advised that the prime minister should be prepared to discuss japan economic issues matsunaga cited issues such as japan micro chip trade pact foreign access to the kansai international airport project and new international telecommunications firm matsunaga returned on sunday to report to japanese leaders on recent developments over trade in preparation for nakasone visit to washington april 29 to may kyodo quoted nakasone as telling reporters after meeting the envoy entirely accept what ambassador matsunaga recommended nakasone did not elaborate the japan trade dispute intensified last week when president ronald reagan said the would impose heavy tariffs on japanese imports in retaliation against alleged japanese breach of the computer chip trade pact meanwhile nakasone ruling liberal democratic party ldp is to consider measures to boost imports and open up the japanese market such as government purchase of supercomputers and expanding foreign access to the kansai airport project party sources said the ldp international economic affairs council was responding to nakasone request for measures to reduce japan increasing trade surpluses with the and europe they said
key house trade subcommittee approves bill to toughen trade laws

japan cuts chip supply may produce shortage japan is attempting to cut back semiconductor production to forstall the 300 mln dlrs in tariffs on japanese electronic goods set to take effect april 17 industry analysts said the move is likely to create sharp price rise and possible shortage of the key computer components in the next few weeks the analysts said prices have gone up for memory components the mainstay of the japanese semiconductor industry analyst drew peck of donaldson lufkin and jenrette said but analysts said the price rises have been slight so far and some questioned whether japan would be successful in forcing japanese companies to cut production in the long run others however were more optimistic saying evidence was already in hand that japan has cut back prodution and halted sales to the grey market the third country brokers that sell chips at below production costs we ve seen the grey market begin to dry up for rams and it has virtually dried up for eproms said merrill lynch analyst thomas kurlack of the two key memory chips used in computers prices are inching up and lead times on deliveries are stretching kurlack added industry analysts said japan ministry of international trade and industry or miti had requested the cut backs in production to meet the terms of last year semiconductor accord with the the reagan adminsitration recently proposed tariffs on japanese electronic goods alleging that japan had failed to live up to the accord and continued to dump the computer components in the market but some analysts said japan attempt to mollify the was double edged sword and might be read at subtle form of trade retaliation for the tariffs proposed by the as production in japan is cut these analysts argue prices will rise in the and few american semiconductor manufactures will be able to take up the slack since most long ago exited the market for memory chips computer makers that use the chips in their machines will then be pressured the japanese are looking for ways to reduce trade pressures from washington but at the same time they re demonstating their muscle analyst peck said the cut backs in japanese production are expected to benefit chip makers think this could be very important factor for semiconductor manufacturers industry analyst elliot levine of ladenburg thalmann co said but analyst peck said it will take few weeks to see whether japan has genuinely cut production he said japanese manufactures were likely to view miti request unfavorably because chip capacity was still high and production cut backs would lead to significant write offs in plant and equipment

japan trade surplus will grow again in 1987 oecd japan trade surplus is likely to continue to grow in 1987 as sales of japanese goods abroad increase while domestic demand remains sluggish the organization for economic cooperation and development oecd said in its latest half yearly review of the world economy the oecd said japan managed to considerably reduce its surplus last year when domestic demand grew by four pct in 1986 while export markets rose by only two pct but it said this differential between the growth of domestic and foreign demand would reverse in 1987 and 1988 thus weakening the international adjustment process it forecast slowing in domestic growth to little over two pct but with rise in exports of pct in 1987 and pct in 1988 as result the current account surplus in 1987 will rise to 95 billion dlrs from 86 billion in 1986 although in 1988 it should fall back to 87 billion dlrs the oecd outlook did not take account of the 000 billion yen package announced last month to stimulate domestic demand and increase imports to japan however oecd officials said the measures will significantly strengthen domestic demand quite possibly exceeding one pct gnp when the full effects have worked through and thus will provide some stimulus to imports the oecd outlook said continued large current account surpluses and the further build up of an already substantial net external asset position could well lead to upward pressure on the yen it said that further appreciation could then lead manufacturers to postpone their investment plans and thus weaken domestic growth the oecd said japan gross national product was likely to gorw an annual two pct in 1987 and 1988 below 1986 pct growth but it said japan would continue its good performance on inflation with zero figure expected in 1987 compared to pct rise in consumer prices last year

current account deficit 36 84 billion dlrs the current account deficit widened to record 36 84 billion dlrs on balance of payments basis in the october december fourth quarter of 1986 from revised 35 29 billion dlrs in the third quarter the commerce department said previously the department said the third quarter deficit was 36 28 billion dlrs for the full year 1986 the current account broad measure of trade performance was in deficit record 140 57 billion dlrs after 117 68 billion dlr deficit in 1985 the department said an increase in the merchandise trade deficit during the fourth quarter to 38 billion dlrs from 37 billion dlrs in the third quarter was the main reason for the worsening deficit net service receipts declined to billion dlrs in the final quarter from six billion dlrs in the third quarter the current account includes trade in merchandise and services as well as financial transactions with the rest of the world the department said the merchandise trade deficit for all of 1986 grew to 147 billion from 124 billion dlrs in 1985 net service receipts were 22 billion dlrs in 1986 compared with 21 billion dlrs in 1985 the department said net unilateral transfers during the fourth quarter last year covering foreign aid and government pensions were down to billion dlrs from billion dlrs in the third quarter because of fewer government grants to mideast countries liabilities to foreigners reported by banks rose 35 billion dlrs between october and december after increasing 30 billion dlrs in the third quarter for the full year these liabilities grew 77 billion dlrs after rising by 40 billion dlrs in 1985 the department said inflows were boosted in the fourth quarter by international activities of japanese banks and strong demand within the united states to finance acquisitions net foreign sales of treasury securities by foreigners were billion dlrs in the quarter after purchases of 500 mln dlrs in the third quarter net foreign purchases of securities other than treasury securities in the fourth quarter were 11 billion dlrs compared with 17 billion dlrs in the third quarter for all 1986 foreign purchases of securities excluding treasury securities were record 70 billion dlrs surpassing the previous record 50 billion dlr total in 1985 claims on foreigners reported by banks in the fourth quarter rose 29 billion dlrs after 19 billion dlr third quarter increase sales of foreign securities rose to billion dlrs from 300 mln dlrs in the third quarter because of sharp selloff of foreign stocks and bonds the department said outflows for direct investment abroad fell to billion dlrs from eight billion dlrs in the third quarter foreign direct investment in the united states increased 14 billion dlrs in the fourth quarter compared with billion dlrs in the previous quarter because of stepped up acquisitions the department said foreign official assets in the united states increased 800 mln dlrs between october and december after rising 15 billion dlrs in the third quarter for the full year 1986 foreign official assets grew 33 billion dlrs after 1985 decrease of billion dlrs as foreign monetary authorities intervened heavily
